text:
Van Cortlandt Park (Bronx): The Van Cortlandt saw and grist mill at the lower end of Van Cortlandt Lake. The mill burned down in 1901 after having been struck by lightning.

1899

Gift of Randall Comfort
title: Bronx: Van Cortlandt Park.

text:
Van Cortlandt Park (Bronx): The remains of the Van Cortlandt graveyard, burial ground of the early New York families.
Gift of Mott Haven Library
about 1900
title: Bronx: Van Cortlandt Park.

text:
Van Cortlandt Park (Bronx): The Van Cortlandt saw and grist mill at the southernmost tip of Van Cortlandt Lake. The mill burned down in 1901 after having been struck by lightning.

About 1900

Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Bronx: Van Cortlandt Park - Van Cortlandt Mill.

text:
Van Cortlandt Park (Bronx): A front view of the Van Cortlandt House Museum, about 150 yards east of Broadway, on the north side of the road that is the extension within the park of W. 246th Street. The house was built by Frederick Van Cortlandt in 1748. The house is maintained as a museum by the Colonial Dames.

About 1900

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Van Cortlandt Park (Bronx): The Van Cortlandt House Museum, the former residence of the Van Cortlandts, built in 1748 and now maintained by the Colonial Dames. The estate was purchased by the City of New York to be used as a park in 1889.

Gift of Randall Comfort

(2)

Another view of the Van Cortlandt House.

About 1900

1981
title: Bronx: Van Cortlandt Park.

text:
Van Cortlandt Park: A view of the cairn of stones on Indian Field. The cairn is situated on the west side of Van Cortlandt Park East, at the head of West 237th Street and is dedicated to the Stockbridge Indians. The inscription of the tablet reads:

August 31, 1778.
Upon this field
Chief Nimham
And seventeen Stockbridge Indians
As Allies of the Patriots,
Gave their lives for Liberty.

Erected by Bronx Chapter,
Daughters of the American Revolution
Mount Vernon, N.Y.

June 14, 1906.

Gift of Randall Comfort.

1906.
title: Bronx: Van Cortlandt Park - cairn of stones on Indian Field.

text:
Van Cortlandt Park (Bronx): Viewing west across the lower end of Van Cortland Lake as it is being filled. On the left is the 242nd Street I.R.T. subway station, on Broadway; on the right is the Horace Mann High School, on West 246th Street.

About 1917
title: Bronx: Van Cortlandt Park.

text:
Nagle Avenue, Inwood, looking north from St. Nicholas Avenue and Dyckman Street.

October 26, 1927.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

VAN CORTLANDT MANSION  Van Cortlandt Park, Bronx. Built in 1784 by Frederick Van Cortlandt, this Georgian mansion was visited by General Washington during the Revolutionary War. The ample stone house has an unpretentious exterior that contrasts strongly with the rich Georgian interior. The estate was held continuously by the Van Cortlandt family until 1889, when it was purchased by the city for a park.

Bank of New York Calendar 1967-68
title: Bronx: Van Cortlandt Park - Van Cortlandt Mansion.
